author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Kindle e-books removed from Waterstones stores in U.K.
text:
Amazon.com, Inc Amazon's Kindle e-readers were removed from multiple Waterstones locations in the U.K. after sales plummeted. For some, there's nothing like holding a physical book and turning the pages with your hands.
The U.K.'s largest retail bookstore - Waterstones - seems to agree as the London-based company decided to remove all of Amazon's Kindle three years after it placed the e-readers up on its shelves.
James Daunt, managing director at Waterstones, said in an interview that Kindle sales from many of its locations had been "pitiful."
"Sales of Kindles continue to be pitiful so we are taking the display space back in more and more shops," Daunt told The Bookseller magazine .
Google Waterstones stops selling Kindle e-books due to 'pitiful sales,' the company's managing director told The Bookseller. "It feels very much like the life of one of those inexplicable bestsellers; one day piles and piles, selling like fury; the next you count your blessings with every sale because it brings you closer to getting it off your shelves forever to make way for something new," he told the magazine.
"Sometimes, of course, they 'bounce' but no sign yet of this being the case with Kindles."
The decision to take down the e-readers comes after paperbacks sales at Waterstones increased by 5% in December 2014, The Guardian reported .
